this is essentially the same fix as #57
Thanks for picking  up this fix so quickly!  You're right, it is mathematically the same fix as #57.  The defect was actually inherited from sff_8436 (the ancestor of optoe).
could you provide a sample output before and after the fix?

Thank you, @lguohan!

The kernel build itself looks straight forward.  I assume there are changes in other SONiC repos in order to move to stretch kernel. To have a complete picture, could you provide links to those PRs here as well?  thanks.
https://github.com/lguohan/sonic-buildimage/tree/stretch
retest this please

Please accept this PR to replace PR #43.

Roy Lee at Accton discovered in his testing that attempts to read beyond the end of devices that do not page results in unexpected error messages. With this patch optoe returns '0' for accesses that start beyond the end of the device (256 bytes for a DAC or a QSFP without pages, 512 bytes for an SFP without pages, 32K+ for paged devices). According to the Linux Device Driver book (LDD3, ch3, page 66), "The return value for read is interpreted by the calling application program... If the value is 0, end-of-file was reached (and no data was read)." This patch implements this policy. Roy has confirmed the unexpected error messages are now gone.

This PR is implemented as a new patch in the 'patch' directory, which will patch optoe.c.  It also updates the 'series' file to apply this patch, after the patch that introduces optoe.c.  

Don

I am not able to find the optoe driver compiled in the kernel build log. Can you check?

https://sonic-jenkins.westus2.cloudapp.azure.com/job/common/job/linux-kernel-pr-build/58/consoleText

I think what is missing here is probably the kernel config, you need to enable to compile your driver as a kernel module. check this patch for sff_8436 driver.

https://github.com/Azure/sonic-linux-kernel/blob/master/patch/config-dell-s6000.patch#L45
